statement.p: Graph the equation \displaystyle{y}={\left({4}^{{{x}+{1}}}\right)}+{3}. You will select a point on the asymptote (only y coordinate matters); then you select two points on the exponential.

solution.p: Because \displaystyle{y}={\left({4}^{{{x}+{1}}}\right)}+{3} has \displaystyle+{3} at the end, the asymptote is at \displaystyle{y}={3}.
One convenient point is where \displaystyle{x}+{1}={0} which is \displaystyle{x}=-{1}. Here \displaystyle{y}={4}.
A second convenient point is one right of -1, which is \displaystyle{x}={0}. Here \displaystyle{y}={7}
